awd_titl_txt: Cyber Security Transition to Practice Workshop #2: Creating a TTP Roadmap
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Networking and Information Technology Research and Development Program (NITRD) Supplement President's Budget FY2016" cites Accelerating Transition to Practice as one of five strategic objectives in the Cyber Security and Information Assurance (CSIA) Program Component Area. However, the NSF cybersecurity portfolio contains only a small amount of security research that has been transitioned into practice. The Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) of the White House defines transition to practice as research that "creates measurable improvements in the cybersecurity landscape". Although NSF encourages security researchers with promising projects to submit TTP (Transition to Practice) projects, a very low percentage of submissions take advantage of the Option. 

In February 2015, NSF sponsored a workshop which brought together key stakeholders to provide insights on how to improve the TTP process and encourage more TTP submissions. An important outcome of that workshop was the identification of specific barriers to TTP. In order to keep momentum going from the February 2015 workshop, this follow-on workshop identifies specific success factors for PI's as they consider how to address TTP in FY16 and following years and overcome previous barriers. It also provides NSF input as to how to shape future years' TTP programs. The expected outcome is that NSF expands the impact of the cybersecurity research it funds and produces more TTP results in the near to mid-term.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A two-day workshop on improving Technology Transfer to Practice (TTP) processes and outcomes was held November 4-5, 2015, in Rosslyn, VA. This workshop brought together 24 participants selected for their significant experience in different aspects of the technology transfer process. These participants were drawn from industry, government, and academia, and included many with experience delivering NSF-sponsored research results into practice. Seven NSF program officers (representing both programs intended to improve TTP rates as well as cybersecurity programs sponsoring research with results likely to be good TTP candidates) participated in this workshop, contributing notable time and energy to the discussions.

The workshop participants identified a number of items as key results of the workshop discussions. These findings (outlined in detail in the final report) addressed a wide range of areas and are notable in that they include both public and private markets for transferred technologies (i.e., they include user populaces that are extremely critical to advancing the state of cybersecurity knowledge, even as they may not generate enough revenue to be of interest as commercial concerns.

General areas addressed include:

1. The need for NSF to acknowledge the value of TTP, to both scientific and general user populaces, by including it as an integral feature in future SaTC solicitations. This includes amending NSF rules to allow researchers to use open source software with payment of user fees (as currently covered for commercial software) as a means of solving ongoing sustainability issues,

2. The need to facilitate PI awareness and collaboration with the full spectrum of NSF programs designed to support TTP activities,

3. The need for a community of support for TTP (an "ecosystem" that provides PI access to  the array of those subject matter experts who are relevant to TTP processes,)

4. The need for TTP training specifically targeting the PI community, as well as the University -level TTP offices, and

5. The importance of maintaining balance between fundamental research activities and those research efforts for which TTP is a desired outcome.

The workshop participants agreed that the discussions were of extreme interest and served to provide deeper understanding of what a functional TTP effort might involve. Findings have already influenced research strategies and policies affecting cybersecurity research. The workshop organizers have also compiled a "How to TTP" guide targeting NSF PIs, as well as website outlining the TTP workshop (which includes a downloadable version of the TTP guide.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2016
Modified by: Rebecca G Bace
